Consider this a bit of a Chinese political thriller because that's how this true life story of intrigue reads.
It starts when a former Chinese police chief, Wang Lijun, walks into a U.S.

The episode and the ensuing Bo Xilai scandal are chronicled in a new book ""A Death in the Lucky Holiday Hotel.

Wenguang Huang, welcome to the program.

So let's start with the death that's in the title of this book.
Could you set the scene for us at the Lucky Holiday Hotel and walk us through the murder of Neil Heywood which made international headlines last year.
The whole incident started on November 15, 2011 in a hotel in the suburbs of Chongqing, one of China's mega city with 32 million people.
The hotel staff members, they found the body of a British man, and then they immediately called the hospital and also the police chief.

Three months later, the police chief of Chongqing, he showed up at the American Consulate in Chengdu and asked for political asylum.

Not only that, the murderer, allegedly, was Gu Kailai, the wife of Bo Xilai, the party chief of Chongqing.
As you could imagine, this whole thing set off a political crisis.
So suddenly, this has gone to implicate all these high officials within the state, and on top of that, this is a very important time in the political calendar for the Chinese Communist Party.
Exactly.
In October 2012, the Communist Party was supposed to have the leadership transition.
It happens once in every 10 years.
And then the party chief of Chongqing, he was a very promising candidate.
He was supposed to join the highest decision-making body, the Politburo Standing Committee.

And they started at 10 o'clock and finished everything by 5 o'clock.
They wanted to get the trial done before the Communist Party Congress.
If the wife was convicted, it would've justified the action to remove the husband from this important position.
So the trial was conducted without the presence of any witnesses.
The court did not consider any of the opinions of the defense lawyers, and then so Gu Kailai was convicted very easily.
